{{About||the album|Blurred Lines (album)|blurred lines in photography|Defocus aberration}} {{pp-move-dispute|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox song | name = Blurred Lines | cover = Robin Thicke Blurred Lines Cover.svg | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Robin Thicke]] featuring [[T.I.]] and [[Pharrell Williams|Pharrell]] | album = [[Blurred Lines (album)|Blurred Lines]] | released = March 20, 2013 | format = {{hlist|[[CD single|CD]]|[[maxi single|maxi CD]]|[[music download|digital download]]}} | recorded = 2012 | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist |[[Disco]]|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]}} | length = 4:25 | label = {{hlist|[[Star Trak Entertainment|Star Trak]]|[[Interscope Records|Interscope]]}} | writer = {{hlist|[[Robin Thicke]]|[[Pharrell Williams]]|[[T.I.|Clifford Harris Jr.]]|[[Marvin Gaye]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/11/business/media/blurred-lines-infringed-on-marvin-gaye-copyright-jury-rules.html |title='Blurred Lines' Infringed on Marvin Gaye Copyright, Jury Rules |first1=Ben |last1=Sisario |first2=Noah |last2=Smith |date=March 11, 2015 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>}} | producer = [[Pharrell Williams]] | chronology = [[Robin Thicke]] | prev_title = [[Love After War (song)|Love After War]] | prev_year = 2011 | next_title = [[For the Rest of My Life]] | next_year = 2013 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[T.I.]] | type = single | prev_title = [[We Still in This Bitch]] | prev_year = 2013 | title = Blurred Lines | year = 2013 | next_title = [[Pour It Up#Remix|Pour It Up (Remix)]] | next_year = 2013 }} {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Pharrell Williams]] | type = single | prev_title = [[Celebrate (Mika song)|Celebrate]] | prev_year = 2012 | title = Blurred Lines | year = 2013 | next_title = [[Get Lucky (Daft Punk song)|Get Lucky]] | next_year = 2013 }} {{External music video|{{YouTube|yyDUC1LUXSU|"Blurred Lines"}}}} }}
"'''Blurred Lines'''" is a single written and performed by American recording artists [[Robin Thicke]], [[T.I.]], and [[Pharrell Williams]]. Produced by Pharrell, it serves as the lead single from [[Blurred Lines (album)|Thicke's album of the same name]]. It was released on March 26, 2013 through Pharrell's label [[Star Trak]] Recordings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/blurred-lines-feat.-t.i.-pharrell/id621507456|title=Blurred Lines (feat. T.I. & Pharrell) – Single|date=March 26, 2013|work=iTunes|publisher=Apple|accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> Recorded in 2012, the song's percussion ideas were primarily inspired by the [[Marvin Gaye]] song "[[Got to Give It Up]]", and apart from T.I.'s rap, was entirely the work of Williams.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/robin-thicke-jealous-of-pharrell-williams-while-creating-blurred-lines-admits-being-high-during-oprah-interview-20140916-10hezf.html |title=Robin Thicke jealous of Pharrell Williams while creating Blurred Lines, admits being high during Oprah interview |date=September 16, 2014 |newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity-life/celebrities-gone-bad/robin-thicke-i-was-too-high-and-drunk-to-write-blurred-lines/news-story/facde5c5eb8e617512446ae6e32b8148 |title=Thicke: 'I was too drunk to write Blurred Lines' |website=[[News.com.au]] |date=September 16, 2014|accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/robin-thicke-s-hit-blurred-lines-lands-him-in-court-and-he-had-almost-no-part-in-writing-it-9736734.html |title=Robin Thicke’s hit 'Blurred Lines' lands him in court, and he had almost no part in writing it |date=September 16, 2014 |first=Tim |last=Walker |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref> However, Thicke clearly laid claim to writing credits on the track according to a Reuters article.<ref>{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Fleeman |date=March 10, 2015 |title=Marvin Gaye's heirs win $7.4 million for 'Blurred Lines' plagiarism |website=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/10/music-blurred-copyright-idUSL1N0WC2TE20150310}}</ref> The song became the subject of a bitter legal dispute with the family of Gaye and [[Bridgeport Music]] as to whether the song infringed copyrights to "Got to Give It Up". Thicke and Williams were found liable for copyright infringement by a federal jury in March 2015, and Gaye was awarded posthumous songwriting credit based on the royalties pledged to his estate.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3161742/Judge-trims-Blurred-Lines-song-dispute-verdict-5-3M.html |title=Judge trims Blurred Lines song dispute verdict to $5.3million |date=July 15, 2015 |newspaper=The Daily Mail |accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>
The song's [[music video]] was released in two versions, with one featuring models [[Emily Ratajkowski]], Jessi M'Bengue, and [[Elle Evans]] being topless, while the other censored nudity. The uncut version of the video was at one time removed from YouTube for violating the site's [[terms of service]] regarding nudity; it was later restored, but with an age restriction. The song's lyrics and music video have proven controversial with some groups, with claims that it is [[misogyny|misogynistic]] and promotes [[date rape]]. This has led to the song being banned at some [[students' unions]] in universities and other institutions in the [[United Kingdom]] and prompted a rebuttal from Thicke.
"Blurred Lines" peaked at number one in at least 25 countries and became the number one song of 2013 in several of them. It became Thicke's first, T.I.'s fourth, and Pharrell's third number-one single in the US, where it was also the longest running number one single of 2013. The song subsequently became [[List of best-selling singles|one of the best-selling singles of all time]], with sales of 14.8 million,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/mar/18/music-sales-ifpi-2013-spotify-streaming |title=Global music sales fell in 2013 despite strong growth for streaming services |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> simultaneously breaking the record for the largest radio audience in history.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|title=Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' sets radio audience record, label says|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-robin-thickes-blurred-lines-radio-audience-record-20130726,0,4749230.story|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=30 July 2013|first=Mikael|last=Wood|date=July 26, 2013}}</ref> The single was nominated for two Grammys at the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards]], including [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance|Best Pop Duo/Group Performance]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5819883/grammy-awards-2014-full-nominations-list-complete-nominees|title=Grammy Awards 2014: Full Nominations List|work=Billboard}}</ref> The song has been parodied and [[cover version|covered]] numerous times.
== Background == "Blurred Lines" was produced by Thicke and Pharrell with an intention of creating a sound similar to Marvin Gaye's "[[Got to Give It Up]]" (1977). The song was completed in less than an hour.<ref name=reuter>{{cite web|last=Reuter|first=Annie|title=Robin Thicke On His First No. 1, 'Blurred Lines': 'We Didn't Know It Would Be This Big'|url=http://news.radio.com/2013/06/12/robin-thicke-on-his-first-no-1-blurred-lines-we-didnt-know-it-would-be-this-big/|publisher=[[Radio.com]]|accessdate=June 14, 2013}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[GQ]]'s'' Stelios Phili, Thicke explained:
{{quote|Pharrell and I were in the studio and [...] I was like, "Damn, we should make something like that ['Got to Give It Up'], something with that groove." Then he started playing a little something and we literally wrote the song in about half an hour and recorded it. He and I would go back and forth where I'd sing a line and he'd be like, "Hey, hey, hey!" We started acting like we were two old men on a porch hollering at girls like, "Hey, where you going, girl? Come over here!"<ref name=phili>{{cite web|last=Phili|first=Stelios|title=Robin Thicke on That Banned Video, Collaborating with 2 Chainz and Kendrick Lamar, and His New Film|url=https://www.gq.com/blogs/the-feed/2013/05/robin-thicke-interview-blurred-lines-music-video-collaborating-with-2-chainz-and-kendrick-lamar-mercy.html|publisher=''[[GQ]]''|accessdate=June 14, 2013}}</ref>}}
In a separate interview, Thicke clarified the meaning of the song's title, saying it referred to "the good-girl/bad-girl thing and what's appropriate".<ref name=payne>{{cite web|last=Payne|first=Chris|title=Robin Thicke Talks 'Happier' New Album, Calls 'Blurred Lines' Video 'Semi-Existential'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/1561343/robin-thicke-talks-happier-new-album-calls-blurred-lines-video|publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''|accessdate=June 14, 2013}}</ref>
Thicke and manager Jordan Feldstein decided the song would not have much impact through radio and would need an innovative approach to become a hit.<ref name="hitquarters.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_JFeldstein.html |title=Interview with Jordan Feldstein |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=October 30, 2013 |accessdate=October 31, 2013}}</ref> Feldstein told [[HitQuarters]]: "We had an artist that had never had a hit on radio. It was a non-traditional song; it didn't sound like a [[Timbaland]] or [[Benny Blanco]] record. So we had to approach the market in an interesting way." Feldstein came up with the idea of creating a video designed to go viral and brought in experienced music video director [[Diane Martel]] to shoot it. Its controversial nature was designed to attract attention with Feldstein saying: "I knew it would get it banned quickly ... Getting something banned actually helps you."<ref name="hitquarters.com" />
== Music videos == The [[music video]], directed by [[Diane Martel]], was released on March 20, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robin Thicke – Blurred Lines ft. T.I., Pharrell|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yyDUC1LUXSU|work=YouTube|accessdate=April 6, 2013}}</ref> The video features Thicke, T.I. and Pharrell casually standing in front of light-pink backdrop as they flirt with models ([[Emily Ratajkowski]], [[Lindsey Evans|Elle Evans]] and Jessi M'Bengue) who pose and dance. At various points, the [[hashtag]] "#THICKE" flashes, whilst towards the end, "ROBIN THICKE HAS A BIG DICK" is spelled out in silver balloons. In the unrated version of the video, the models wear just [[thong (clothing)|thongs]]. In the edited version, they are scantily clad and the hashtag "#BLURREDLINES" is seen at various points. This is the second time that director Diane Martel and Pharrell join together for a music video project involving two differently rated versions. The 2001 video for the N.E.R.D single "[[Lapdance (song)|Lapdance]]" also featured models in two variant editions, one of which, like "Blurred Lines", is a topless version.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scott Kara: Nudey rudey comeback|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10879566|newspaper=The New Zealand Herald | date=April 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title="Lapdance" (uncensored version)|url=https://www.dailymotion.com/video/xzd32_nerd-lap-dance-uncensored-version_music|newspaper=Dailymotion|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422170140/http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xzd32_nerd-lap-dance-uncensored-version_music|archivedate=April 22, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The video was filmed at Mack Sennett Studios in [[Silver Lake, Los Angeles|Silver Lake]].
After being on the site for just under one week, the unrated version of the video was removed from [[YouTube]] on March 30, 2013, citing violations of the site's [[terms of service]] that restricts the uploading of videos containing nudity, particularly if used in a sexual context.<ref name="Blurred Banned">{{cite news|title='Blurred Lines' Banned By YouTube As Robin Thicke's Video Features Nude Models|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/01/blurred-lines-banned-by-youtube-robin-thicke-nude-models_n_2994676.html|work=''[[Huffington Post]]'' (via the [[Associated Press]])|date=April 1, 2013|accessdate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> However it was later restored on July 12, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Officially NSFW: YouTube's Naked Lady Problem (NSFW) (Updated)|url=https://gizmodo.com/5993196/officially-nsfw-youtubes-naked-lady-problem|work=[[Gizmodo]]|date=April 1, 2013|accessdate=April 6, 2013|author=Peter Ha}}</ref> The unrated video remains available on [[Vevo]], while the edited version is available on both Vevo and YouTube.<ref>{{cite news|title='Blurred Lines' Banned By YouTube As Robin Thicke's Video Features Nude Models|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/01/blurred-lines-banned-by-youtube-robin-thicke-nude-models_n_2994676.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=April 6, 2013|date=April 1, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gicas|first=Peter|title=Robin Thicke's "Blurred Lines" Topless Music Video Banned from YouTube|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/403774/robin-thicke-s-blurred-lines-topless-music-video-banned-from-youtube|work=E! Online|accessdate=April 6, 2013|date=April 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Robin Thicke's music video 'Blurred Lines' banned by YouTube for featuring nude models|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/robin-thicke-music-video-blurred-lines-banned-youtube-article-1.1305382|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=April 6, 2013|author=Chiderah Monde}}</ref> The unrated version of "Blurred Lines" generated more than 1 million views in the days following its release on Vevo.<ref name="Blurred Banned" /> As of February 2018, the unrated version of "Blurred Lines" is available on YouTube and has gathered more than 55 million views.<ref>{{cite web|title= Blurred Lines Unrated Version on YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zwT6DZCQi9k|accessdate=March 4, 2014}}</ref>
=== Concept and background === {{quote box|quote="I wanted to have beautiful bodies and crazy, fucked-up sets. I thought about cheap props, crappy fun stuff. The video is goofy and innocent. I was channeling [[The Benny Hill Show|Benny Hill]] and 1960s variety shows."|source=—Diane Martel Q&A with Eric Ducker, ''Grantland'', June 26, 2013.<ref name=Grant />|width =25% |align=right}} During a Q&A for ''[[Grantland]]'' Diane Martel explained that her desire was "to make videos that sell records" and "not to make videos that express my own obsessions, but to make videos that move units." Martel at first turned down the offer to direct the video after being told there could be no nudity but agreed to direct when it was decided to shoot two versions. The video was shot as a white [[cyclorama]]. Martel favorably referred to the large hashtags that flash throughout the video as "awkward" and noted she enjoyed their obstructive quality. The fashion in which the women in the video are dressed was in part inspired by the work of photographer [[Helmut Newton]]. When asked about what references she drew from for the video, Martel cited the ballets of [[George Balanchine]] as performed by the [[New York City Ballet]], noting their [[minimalism]], as well as the work of [[Richard Avedon]]. The manner in which Martel directed the action and interaction of those in the video was intended to convey playfulness while also presenting the women "in the power position." Martel also sought out intentionally "gross" and "oversized" props to utilize in the video.<ref name=Grant />
== Reception == {{listen | filename = Robin Thicke + Pharell Williams + T.I. - Blurred Lines.ogg | title="Blurred Lines" | description = A sample of "Blurred Lines" | pos = left }} Critical reactions to ''Blurred Lines'' were mostly positive. ''[[The Michigan Daily]]'''s Jackson Howard graded it an "A" and praised it as "one of Pharrell's best beats in years ... by the time the multilayered and carnal harmonies of the chorus come in, the song is completely on fire."<ref name=howard>{{cite web|last=Howard|first=Jackson|title=Single Review: Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' successfully samples classic beats for layered product|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/arts/04single-review-robin-thickes-blurred-lines-successfully-samples-classic-beats-produce-layered-pr04|publisher=''[[The Michigan Daily]]''|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> Writing for ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', Chris Payne compared it with [[Justin Timberlake]]'s "[[Suit & Tie]]" and called it a "bubbly bit of disco-shuffling R&B", while also noting its racy content.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|last=Payne|first=Chris|title=R&B Single Review: "Blurred Lines" Robin Thicke|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1558928/rb-single-review-blurred-lines-robin-thicke|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> [[Digital Spy]]'s Lewis Corner, who gave the song three out of five stars, was more wary of the single and remarked: "It's a subject that when in the right hands can be smooth and soulful, but in the wrong, crass and chauvinistic ... you need the right balance of charm and swagger to pull it off."<ref name=corner>{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Lewis|title=Robin Thicke ft. Pharrell & TI: 'Blurred Lines' – Single review|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/singlesreviews/a483266/robin-thicke-ft-pharrell--ti-blurred-lines-single-review.html|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref> ''[[The Village Voice]]''{{'}}s [[Pazz & Jop]] annual critics' poll ranked "Blurred Lines" at number four to find the best music of 2013, tied with [[Kanye West]]'s "[[New Slaves]]".
On the other hand, [[Rob Sheffield]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' named the song "The Worst Song of This or Any Other Year."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/blurred-lines-the-worst-song-of-this-or-any-other-year-20131206|title='Blurred Lines': The Worst Song Of This Or Any Other Year – Rolling Stone|work=Rolling Stone}}</ref>
Music fans voted "Blurred Lines" second in a 2014 ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out Sydney]]'' poll of the worst songs ever recorded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sydneyland.au.timeout.com/2014/02/07/whats-the-worst-song-ever-written-the-nottest-100-winner-is-revealed/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918163202/http://sydneyland.au.timeout.com/2014/02/07/whats-the-worst-song-ever-written-the-nottest-100-winner-is-revealed/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 September 2015|title=What's the worst song ever written? The Nottest 100 winner is revealed!|last=Street|first=Andrew P|date=7 February 2014|website=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out Sydney]]|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref>
== Chart performance == "Blurred Lines" peaked at number one in 25 countries, including the United Kingdom, Australia, Republic of Ireland, France, Germany, Austria, Italy, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Poland, Canada, New Zealand and the United States, becoming Thicke's highest charting song in all of these countries. In Australia, the song was certified quadruple platinum for shipments of 280,000 and triple platinum in New Zealand for sales of 45,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesaria-charts-accreditations-singles-2013.htm |title=ARIA Charts – Accreditations – 2013 Singles |publisher=Aria.com.au |date=May 31, 2013 |accessdate=June 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JdeckIt9?url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesaria-charts-accreditations-singles-2013.htm |archivedate=September 15, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> "Blurred Lines" peaked within the top five of 14 countries including France and Switzerland. The song is currently the longest-running number-one single of 2013 in Australia and New Zealand, having topped the ARIA Singles Chart for eight consecutive weeks in Australia, and the RIANZ Singles Chart for 11 non-consecutive weeks in New Zealand.<ref name="Blurred Lines">{{cite web|url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/chart/singles |title=ARIA Australian Top 50 Singles Chart |publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) |date=2013-07-01 |accessdate=2013-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141202075455/http://www.ariacharts.com.au/chart/singles |archivedate=December 2, 2014 |df= }}</ref> For the Latin American market, a version featuring Colombian rapper [[J Balvin]] was released on Spanish-language radio stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caracol.com.co/noticias/entretenimiento/j-balvin-se-codea-con-pharrel-y-robin-thicke/20130619/nota/1918630.aspx|title=J Balvin se codea con Pharrel y Robin Thicke|language=Spanish|work=[[Caracol Radio]]|publisher=[[PRISA]]|date=June 19, 2013|accessdate=July 1, 2013}}</ref> This version peaked at number 7 in Colombia.<ref name="Colombia" />
In the United States, the song debuted at number 94 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot 100]],<ref name="rap-up.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/05/14/video-robin-thicke-pharrell-ti-perform-blurred-lines-on-the-voice/#more-157885 |title=Robin Thicke, Pharrell, & T.I. Perform 'Blurred Lines' on 'The Voice' |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date=May 14, 2013 |accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref> the following week the song rose to number 89, then to number 70, then to number 54.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/05/16/video-robin-thicke-and-pharrell-perform-blurred-lines-on-ellen/|title=Robin Thicke and Pharrell Perform 'Blurred Lines' on 'Ellen' |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date=May 16, 2013 |accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref> The single's progress appeared to stabilize in middle of the U.S. charts when, in mid-May, Robin Thicke and Pharrell performed it live on NBC's ''[[The Voice (US TV series)|The Voice]]''. Immediately afterwards the song flew up to number 12 on the Hot 100.<ref>{{cite news|last=Everett |first=Matthew |title=Summer Jams: Daft Punk, Robin Thicke, and Miguel Compete for Song of the Summer |url=http://www.metropulse.com/news/2013/jul/03/summer-jams-daft-punk-robin-thicke-and-miguel-comp/?print=1 |newspaper=[[Metro Pulse]] newspaper, Knoxville, Tennessee |date=3 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019050542/http://www.metropulse.com/news/2013/jul/03/summer-jams-daft-punk-robin-thicke-and-miguel-comp/?print=1 |archivedate=October 19, 2013 }}</ref> Not long thereafter it peaked at number one, becoming Thicke's highest peaking song on the chart in his recording history. It also became Thicke's first chart entry since "[[Sex Therapy (song)|Sex Therapy]]" and his second top 20 ever, after "[[Lost Without U]]". The track is also Pharrell's third Billboard Hot 100 number one single and T.I.'s fourth. As of June 12, 2013, "Blurred Lines" has sold 1 million copies in the United States since its release, becoming Thicke's first single to do so.<ref name="Blurred Number 1">{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1566519/robin-thickes-blurred-lines-hits-no-1-on-hot-100 | title=Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' Hits No. 1 on Hot 100 | publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=June 12, 2013 | accessdate=June 12, 2013 | author=Trust, Gary}}</ref> As of the chart issue dated September 7, 2013, the song is the longest-running number-one single of 2013 with 12 weeks at the top.<ref name="Robin & Marvin">{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-aug-25-2013-songs-robin-marvin-191212316.html |title=Week Ending Aug. 25, 2013. Songs: Robin & Marvin |last=Grein |first=Paul |publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]] |work=[[Nielsen SoundScan]] |date=2013-08-28 |accessdate=2013-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222063740/https://www.yahoo.com/music/bp/week-ending-aug-25-2013-songs-robin-marvin-191212316.html |archivedate=December 22, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The song is also the first to claim the top "Digital Gainer", top "Airplay Gainer" and the top "Streaming Gainer" simultaneously, and to be awarded the top "Airplay Gainer" for 9 (and afterwards 10) weeks.<ref name="Blurred Number 1" /><ref name="Blurred Records">{{cite web|title=Robin Thicke Extends Hot 100 Run to Nine Weeks, Sets Audience and Sales Record|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5638328/robin-thicke-extends-hot-100-run-to-nine-weeks-sets-audience-and-sales-records|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> As of August 8, it also broke the record for the all-time highest number of radio impressions during a single week in the US, with 219.8 million impressions (which it later extended to 228.9 million impressions the week after), surpassing the eight-year-old record of 212.2 million impressions, set by [[Mariah Carey]]'s "[[We Belong Together (Mariah Carey song)|We Belong Together]]", and is the first song to have four or more weeks of [[music download|downloads]] of over 400,000 in the US.<ref name="Blurred Records" /> On week ending September 14, 2013 it was knocked off number one by [[Katy Perry]] with her single "[[Roar (song)|Roar]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5680131/katy-perry-dethrones-robin-thicke-atop-hot-100|work=Billboard|title=Katy Perry Dethrones Robin Thicke Atop Hot 100|first=Gary|last=Trust|date=2013-09-04|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref> Blurred Lines was also the No. 1 song of the year on iHeart Radio's Top 100 Countdown for 2013. It became the best-selling song of 2013 in the US, selling 6,498,000 downloads in 2013.<ref name="yahoosales">{{cite news |url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/music-news/chart-watch-top-10-albums-songs-2013-184702481.html |title=The Top 10 Albums and Songs of 2013 | author= Paul Grein |date=January 2, 2014 |work=Chart Watch |publisher=Yahoo }}</ref> By April 2014, the single had reached its 7 million mark in sales, taking 56 weeks to reach this mark.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/chart-watch-former-teen-stars-good-215046577.html |title=Chart Watch: Former Teen Stars Make Good! |work=[[Yahoo! Music]] |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |date=April 23, 2014 |accessdate=April 27, 2014 |author=Grein, Paul}}</ref>
In Canada, the song reached number one for 13 consecutive weeks, becoming the longest-running number-one single of 2013. Since the launch of the [[Canadian Hot 100]] in 2007, the song has become third with most weeks at number one, tying "[[Apologize (OneRepublic song)|Apologize]]" by [[Timbaland]] featuring [[OneRepublic]], and just behind "[[Uptown Funk]]" by [[Mark Ronson]] featuring [[Bruno Mars]] and "[[I Gotta Feeling]]" by [[The Black Eyed Peas]], with 15 and 16 weeks on top of the charts respectively.<ref>[[Billboard Canadian Hot 100#Songs with most weeks at number one]]</ref> It was Canada's best-selling song of 2013 with 692,000 copies sold (706,000 for all versions combined).<ref name="canada sales">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/record-labels/5869529/canadas-digital-music-sales-rise-in-2013-unlike-the-us|title=Canada's Digital Music Sales Rise in 2013 Unlike the U.S.; Eminem, Robin Thicke Among Top Selling Artists|last=Bliss|first=Karen|date=January 10, 2014|accessdate=January 11, 2014|work=Billboard}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom, the song debuted at number one on the [[UK Singles Chart]] on June 2, 2013 ― for the week ending date June 8, 2013 ― selling 190,000 copies in its first week and becoming Britain's fastest-selling single of the year, though it was later passed by [[Avicii]]'s "[[Wake Me Up (Avicii song)|Wake Me Up]]" on July 21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/robin-thickes-blurred-lines-becomes-fastest-selling-single-of-2013-2254/ |title=Robin Thicke's Blurred Lines becomes fastest selling single of 2013! |publisher=Officialcharts.com |date= |accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref> "Blurred Lines" then remained at number one the following week, selling even more than it did in its first with 199,000 copies sold.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/robin-thicke-beats-own-record-to-score-biggest-one-week-sale-of-the-year-2271/ |title=Robin Thicke beats own record to score biggest one-week sale of the year! |last1=Barstein |first1=Brand |last2=Kreisler |first2=Lauren |date=June 9, 2013 |website=[[Official Charts Company]] |publisher= |accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref> On its fifth week in the charts, the single dropped a place to number two although it shifted a further 100,000 copies, having the fastest one-week sales at number two of 2013 so far. After a two-week break from the top spot, the song returned to number one on July 14, 2013 ― for the week ending date July 20, 2013 ― to claim its fifth week at the top, becoming the first song to spend two weeks off the top-spot before reclaiming the position, since [[Rihanna]]'s single "[[We Found Love]]" in 2011. "Blurred Lines" was confirmed to have sold 1 million copies on its 50th day of release, becoming Pharrell's second song in only a month to achieve that feat in Britain (the other being [[Daft Punk]] collaboration "[[Get Lucky (Daft Punk song)|Get Lucky]]").<ref name="UK million">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/blurred-lines-becomes-uks-latest-million-selling-single-2361/|title=Blurred Lines Becomes UK's Latest Million Selling Single|publisher=officialcharts.com|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> According to the [[Official Charts Company]], the single became Britain's best-selling single of 2013 with sales of 1,472,681 copies.<ref name="uksales2013">{{cite news |url=http://www.musicweek.com/businessanalysis/read/official-charts-analysis-pharrell-williams-hits-no-1-with-106k-sales/057144 |title=Official Charts Analysis: Pharrell Williams hits No.1 with 106k sales |work= Music Week |date=December 29, 2013}}</ref>
On April 21, 2014, it was announced that "Blurred Lines" was the most downloaded song of all time in the UK,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/the-uks-top-100-most-downloaded-tracks-of-all-time-revealed-2942/|title=The UK's Top 100 most downloaded tracks of all-time revealed!|last=Lane|first=Daniel|date=April 21, 2014|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|accessdate=April 21, 2014}}</ref> with digital sales of more than 1.54 million, a total since surpassed by Pharrell Williams' own single "[[Happy (Pharrell Williams song)|Happy]]". Its current UK sales stand at 1,630,000.<ref name="top 40 2015" />
On July 28, 2013, "Blurred Lines" broke the record for radio audience previously held by [[Mariah Carey]]'s "[[We Belong Together (Mariah Carey song)|We Belong Together]]" in 2005. A press release from [[Interscope]] said as of the last week in July 2013, the track reached more than 242.65 million listeners.<ref name="auto" />
''Blurred Lines'' is Thicke's most successful song, being his first to reach number one on the Hot 100 (he previously peaked at number 14 in 2007 with "[[Lost Without U]]"). It also marks Pharrell's third Hot 100 number one, after "[[Drop It Like It's Hot]]" with [[Snoop Dogg]] in 2004 and "[[Money Maker]]" with [[Ludacris]] in 2006, and [[T.I.]]'s fourth Hot 100 number one after "[[My Love (Justin Timberlake song)|My Love"]] with [[Justin Timberlake]] in 2006, and his own singles "[[Whatever You Like (T.I. song)|Whatever You Like]]" and "[[Live Your Life (T.I. song)|Live Your Life]]" in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robin Thicke Chart History for Billboard Hot 100 Singles|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=robin thicke|chart=Bubbling Under Hot 100}}|work=Billboard|accessdate=April 24, 2013}}</ref>
In the United States, the song topped the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 for twelve consecutive weeks, becoming the longest running number one single of 2013 and of the 2010s decade, surpassing [[Rihanna]]'s "[[We Found Love]]" (2011),<ref name="10 weeks US" /> but was later replaced by [[Mark Ronson]]{{'}}s "[[Uptown Funk]]" in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6517180/uptown-funk-longest-leading-hot-100-no-1-2010s|work=Billboard|title=Uptown Funk Is Longest-Leading Hot 100 No. 1 of the 2010s|first=Gary|last=Trust|date=April 1, 2015|accessdate=April 1, 2015}}</ref> This feat also gave him the eighth lead male solo artist in ''Billboard'' history to rack ten or more weeks at the number one spot for a single.<ref name="10 weeks US">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5650672/robin-thicke-leads-hot-100-for-10th-week-katy-perrys-roar-debuts|title=Robin Thicke Leads Hot 100 For 10th Week, Katy Perry's 'Roar' Debuts|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref> It sold over 5 million copies in just 22 weeks in the US, and 6 million in 29 weeks, faster than any other song in digital history.<ref name="Robin & Marvin" /><ref name="chartwatch2013">{{cite news |url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-oct-13-2013-songs-1-205751307.html |title=Week Ending Oct. 13, 2013. Songs: A New #1 (For The Year) |author=Paul Grein |work=Chart Watch |publisher=Yahoo |date=October 16, 2013 }}</ref>
According to the IFPI, by the end of 2013, the song had sold 14.8 million copies, becoming the best selling song of the year worldwide.
As of August 2016, it is currently the [[List of best-selling singles#Best-selling digital singles|seventh best-selling digital single of all time]]. It was the second best-selling song of 2013 in the US and the best-selling song of 2013 in the UK.<ref name="yahoosales" /><ref name="uksales2013" />
== Controversies ==
=== Content, banning, and subject matter === Critics such as Tricia Romano of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' wrote that the song and the [[music video]] trivialize [[sexual consent]]. She asserts that many fans were uncomfortable with both the song and the video. Her article quoted many critics who believe that the song promotes [[rape culture]] because the title "Blurred Lines" and lyrics like "I know you want it" encourage the idea "no doesn't always mean no" and that some [[Rape myth|women who are raped are asking for it]].<ref>Tricia Romano, "[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/06/17/blurred-lines-robin-thicke-s-summer-anthem-is-kind-of-rapey.html 'Blurred Lines,' Robin Thicke's Summer Anthem, Is Kind of Rapey]", ''The Daily Beast'', 17 June 2013.</ref> Criticism was also leveled at the song's video, which has been labelled "eye-poppingly [[misogynist]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jul/21/renault-weather-duchess-of-cambridge|title=Renault's sexist advert drives me absolutely mad|date=July 21, 2013|last=Day|first=Elizabeth|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London}}</ref> In the [[United Kingdom]], more than 20 universities banned the song from use at student events. At the [[University of Edinburgh]], students' association officials stated that the song violates its policy against "rape culture and [[Lad culture|lad banter]]" and promotes an unhealthy attitude towards sex and consent.<ref name=Spiked>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiked-online.com/freespeechnow/fsn_article/the-moral-mccarthyism-of-the-war-on-lads#.VEhbyYW1nxs|title=The moral McCarthyism of the war on lads|last=O'Neill|first=Brendan|date=|accessdate=2014-10-23}}</ref><ref name=GuardianBanned>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/sep/13/blurred-lines-banned-edinburgh-university |title=Blurred Lines banned by Edinburgh University |last=Michaels |first=Sean |date=September 13, 2013 |website=The Guardian }}</ref> It was also banned at other British institutions, including [[Plymouth University]], [[Leeds University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/robin-thicke-0/72776|title=NME News Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' banned by Leeds University – NME.COM|date=September 20, 2013|work=NME.COM}}</ref> [[University of Derby]], [[Queen Mary University of London]], [[Kingston University]], [[University of Bolton]], [[Queen's University Belfast]], [[University of Birmingham]], [[University of East Anglia]], [[University of the West of Scotland]], and a number of [[Oxford University|Oxford]] and [[University of Durham|Durham]] colleges.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/10707937.University_of_Bolton_students__union_bans_controversial_Robin_Thicke_song_Blurred_Lines/|title=University of Bolton students' union bans controversial Robin Thicke song Blurred Lines|work=[[The Bolton News]]|publisher=[[Newsquest]]}}</ref> Students at the [[University of Exeter]] voted for a condemnation of the lyrics to be issued by the Students' Guild.<ref>{{cite news|title=Exeter University students vote against banning Robin Thicke hit 'Blurred Lines'|url=http://www.exeterexpressandecho.co.uk/Exeter-University-students-vote-banning-Robin/story-19990002-detail/story.html}}</ref> In [[Marshfield, Wisconsin]], Lisa Joling, head coach of the Marshfield High School dance team, was fired in August 2013, three days after a halftime performance by her dance class to the song.<ref name=WAOW>{{cite web|last=WAOW|first=MARSHFIELD|title=Marshfield coach fired after "Blurred Lines" dance|url=http://www.waow.com/story/23584436/2013/10/01/marshfield-coach-fired-after-blurred-lines-dance?hpt=us_bn9|publisher=[[WAOW]]|accessdate=October 1, 2013}}</ref>
Jennifer Lai of [[Slate (magazine)|''Slate'']], while noting that the video "undoubtedly objectifies women", countered criticism that the song itself connotes rape by citing lyrics such as "go ahead/get at me" and "So I'm just watchin' and waitin'/ for you to salute the truly pimpin'", among others, in which Robin and T.I. invite the woman's own sexual agency and are "putting the ball in her court".<ref name=Slate /> Lai also states:
{{quote|Someone who says "I know you want it" is probably overly cocky and presumptuous as hell by assuming you/she wants "it," but nothing about "I know you want it" is saying "I know you want it, and I'm going to force you to have it" or "I had sex with you and you didn't consent, but I know you wanted it." Yes, "I know you want it" could be said by a rapist—but so could "Do you want to go to a movie tonight?"<ref name=Slate>{{cite web|last1=Lai|first1=Jennifer|title="Blurred Lines" Is Cocky, Yes. But Rapey? No.|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2013/06/27/robin_thicke_s_blurred_lines_is_cocky_yes_but_rapey_and_misogynistic_no.html|website=Slate.com|accessdate=28 December 2014}}</ref>}}
Thicke, noting that all three male singers are married and have children, said that the [[Diane Martel]]-directed video was [[tongue-in-cheek]].<ref name="phili" /> When defending the song on NBC's ''[[The Today Show]]'', the 36-year-old singer explained that encouraging conversation about the song's content was his intention, saying "It's actually a feminist movement within itself. It's saying that women and men are equals as animals and as power".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pulpinterest.com/music/uk-universities-ban-robin-thicke-blurred-lines/|title=They Don't Want It:UK Universities Ban – Robin Thicke 'Blurred Lines' – Pulp Interest|work=Pulp Interest}}</ref> After its banning at University College London, Thicke declared the song was about his wife, and that after 20 years together, he indeed knew she wanted it from him.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/11/12/robin-thickes-blurred-lines-banned-at-another-british-university/ | work=Time | title=Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' Banned At Another British University – TIME.com | date=November 12, 2013}}</ref> In 2013 and 2014, Thicke and his wife [[Paula Patton]]'s separation and divorce were covered extensively by the [[tabloid press]] including Thicke's efforts to reconcile with Patton.
During an interview with [[NPR]], "Blurred Lines" producer and co-writer Pharrell defended the song, highlighting the lyric "that man is not your maker", saying, "I don't know anything that could be more clear about our position in the song" and "... if you're looking at the lyrics, the power is right there in the woman's hand. That man—me as a human being, me as a man, I'm not your maker, I can't tell you what to do."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2013/12/31/258406317/pharrell-williams-on-juxtaposition-and-seeing-sounds |title=Pharrell Williams On Juxtaposition And Seeing Sounds |work=npr.org |date= December 31, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}</ref> Pharrell reiterated and expounded on his defense during an interview with [[Pitchfork Media]], in response to the idea of the song being "sexually predatory", saying:
{{quote|What would be controversial about it? In "Blurred Lines", the Robin Thicke lyrics are: "You don't need no papers," meaning, "You are not a possession." "That man is not your maker," meaning he is not God—nor can he produce children or women, for that matter. He's a man, so he definitely did not make you...What I was trying to say was: "That man is trying to domesticate you, but you don't need no papers—let me liberate you." But it was misconstrued. When you pull back and look at the entire song, the point is: She's a good girl, and even good girls want to do things, and that's where you have the blurred lines. She expresses it in dancing because she's a good girl. People who are agitated just want to be mad, and I accept their opinion... We got a kick out of making people dance, and that was the intention.<ref>{{Citation | last = Battan| first = Carrie| title = Pharrell Williams|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/update/9343-pharrell/| publisher = Pitchfork.com| date = February 28, 2014 | accessdate = March 6, 2014 }}</ref>}}
In a Q&A for Grantland.com, video director Diane Martel had this to say about the music video:
{{quote|I wanted to deal with the misogynist, funny lyrics in a way where the girls were going to overpower the men. Look at [[Emily Ratajkowski]]'s performance; it's very, very funny and subtly ridiculing. That's what is fresh to me. It also forces the men to feel playful and not at all like predators. I directed the girls to look into the camera, this is very intentional and they do it most of the time; they are in the power position. I don't think the video is sexist. The lyrics are ridiculous, the guys are silly as fuck. That said, I respect women who are watching out for negative images in pop culture and who find the nudity offensive, but I find [the video] meta and playful.<ref name=Grant>{{Citation | last = Ducker| first = Eric| title = Q&A: Veteran Music Video Director Diane Martel on Her Controversial Videos for Robin Thicke and Miley Cyrus|url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/qa-veteran-music-video-director-diane-martel-on-her-controversial-videos-for-robin-thicke-and-miley-cyrus/| publisher = Grantland.com| date = June 26, 2013 | accessdate = February 18, 2014 }}</ref>}}
Thicke at first appears to contradict his claims that the song is about women empowerment in an interview given to ''[[GQ]]'' in May 2013, stating:
{{quote|We tried to do everything that was taboo. Bestiality, drug injections, and everything that is completely derogatory towards women. Because all three of us are happily married with children, we were like, "We're the perfect guys to make fun of this." People say, "Hey, do you think this is degrading to women?" I'm like, "Of course it is. What a pleasure it is to degrade a woman. I've never gotten to do that before. I've always respected women."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gq.com/blogs/the-feed/2013/05/robin-thicke-interview-blurred-lines-music-video-collaborating-with-2-chainz-and-kendrick-lamar-mercy.html |title=Robin Thicke on That Banned Video, Collaborating with 2 Chainz and Kendrick Lamar, and His New Film |work=gq.com |date= May 7, 2013|accessdate=January 26, 2014}}</ref>}}
When asked about this, Diane Martel denied that there was any such intention calling the idea that it was ever discussed and Thicke's ''GQ'' statement "crazy".<ref name=Grant /> Thicke later clarified his comment during an interview for ''[[Oprah's Next Chapter]]'', describing it as a "bad joke", noting that the ''GQ'' interview that was published did not mention that he had been joking back and forth with the interviewer and doing an impersonation of [[Will Ferrell]]'s [[Ron Burgundy]] character while making the remark, thus not providing the facetious context.<ref name=Oprah>[http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/robin-thicke-robin-thicke-on-oprah-s-next-chapter-video.20205.html Oprah Winfrey.''Oprah's Next Chapter''.Season 2, Episode 39, ''Robin Thicke''].2013. Television. Approx. at the 17min 30sec mark. via hotnewhiphop.com.</ref>
In an interview for [[CBC Radio]]'s ''Q'', Thicke dismissed the idea that the song is about a man forcing himself sexually onto a woman as "an impossible reality".<ref name=CBCRadio /> Thicke continues, "For them to take that lyric [''I know you want it''] and not take the lyrics ''that man is not your maker, you're an animal'', and we're equals, and all of the other lyrics that are in the song and only to take ''I know you want it'' from a guy like Ron Burgundy who's standing there going, [does impression of Ron Burgundy] 'I know you want it, baby'. It's a joke. If they can't get the joke, I feel bad for them, but I'm not going to change the joke."<ref name=CBCRadio />
In the interview, Thicke noted that part of video director Diane Martel's intention was to generate attention, but Thicke defended the song, saying: "The song and the video are two completely different things. The song has nothing to do with belittling a woman or misogyny or anything. Obviously, when a guy's standing there fully clothed and the girls are naked, I totally welcome the conversation of what does this video say about men and women, but the song itself, the title, 'Blurred Lines', is about men and woman are equals."<ref name=CBCRadio>{{cite episode |url=http://www.cbc.ca/q/popupaudio.html?clipIds=2400735917|title=Robin Thicke defends Blurred Lines and being 'naughty'|series=Q |credits= Interviewer:Stephen Quinn|network=CBC Radio|airdate= August 14, 2013|}}</ref>
=== Marvin Gaye lawsuit and authorship questions ===
In August 2013, Thicke, Williams, and Harris (T.I.) sued the family of [[Marvin Gaye]] and [[Bridgeport Music]] for a declaratory judgment that "Blurred Lines" did not [[copyright infringement|infringe copyrights]] of the defendants. Gaye's family accused the song's authors of copying the "feel" and "sound" of "Got to Give It Up" (the song that Thicke personally claimed was an influence on "Blurred Lines"), while Bridgeport claimed that the song illegally sampled [[Funkadelic]]'s song "Sexy Ways". The litigation over the songs drew comparisons to that of the 1970s case between [[George Harrison]] and Bright Tunes Music over the song "[[My Sweet Lord]]", which a judge ruled had similarly plagiarized the earlier "[[He's So Fine]]" by [[The Chiffons]]; Harrison later bought the rights to "He's So Fine".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/plagiarism-robin-thicke-my-sweet-lord-music-pharrell-williams-313178 |title=Your Favorite Band Probably Plagiarized More Than ‘Blurred Lines’ |newspaper=[[Newsweek]] |date=November 3, 2015}}</ref> Ultimately, Thicke and Williams (but not T.I.) were found to have infringed the Gaye estate's copyright, and in 2018 the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit]] affirmed liability for millions of dollars in damages.<ref name=Forbes2018>{{cite web|url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/adriennegibbs/2018/03/21/marvin-gaye-wins-blurred-lines-lawsuit-pharrell-robin-thicke-t-i-off-hook/|title=Marvin Gaye's Family Wins 'Blurred Lines' Appeal; Pharrell, Robin Thicke Must Pay |first= Adrienne|last= Gibbs|date= March 23, 2018|access-date= April 1, 2018}}</ref>
In the lawsuit, Gaye's family was accused of making an invalid copyright claim since [[Idea–expression divide|only expressions, not individual ideas]] can be protected.<ref name="thr-blurredripoff">{{cite news|title=Robin Thicke Sues to Protect 'Blurred Lines' from Marvin Gaye's Family (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/robin-thicke-sues-protect-blurred-607492|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=18 August 2013|first=Eriq|last=Gardner|date=August 15, 2013}}</ref> Pharrell Williams responded to the lawsuit by calling the two songs "completely different", further stating: "Just simply go to the piano and play the two. One's minor and one's major. And not even in the same key."<ref name=murrow>{{cite web|last=Murrow|first=Emerald|title=Pharrell Talks About Battle Over 'Blurred Lines'|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory/pharrell-talks-battle-blurred-lines-20245109|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=September 13, 2013|date=September 13, 2013}}</ref> In an interview, [[Questlove]] also echoed Williams' statement, saying:
{{quote|Look, technically it's not plagiarized. It's not the same chord progression. It's a feeling. Because there's a cowbell in it and a [[Rhodes piano|Fender Rhodes]] as the main instrumentation—that still doesn't make it plagiarized. We all know it's derivative. That's how Pharrell works. Everything that Pharrell produces is derivative of another song—but it's a homage.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.vulture.com/2013/09/questlove-on-his-new-album-with-elvis-costello.html |title=Questlove on His New Album With Elvis Costello |work=Vulture |first= Jody|last= Rosen |date= 2013-08-18|accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref>}}
In September 2014, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' released files relating to a [[Deposition (law)|deposition]] from the case. Within the deposition Thicke stated that, he was "high on Vicodin and alcohol when [he] showed up at the studio", and that as a result, "Pharrell had the beat and he wrote almost every single part of the song".<ref name=Authorship>{{cite web|last1=O'Neal|first1=Sean|title=Robin Thicke says he can't be blamed for "Blurred Lines" because he was high|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/robin-thicke-says-he-cant-be-blamed-blurred-lines--209267|website=A.V Club|accessdate=September 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gardner|first1=Eric|title=Robin Thicke Admits Drug Abuse, Lying to Media in Wild "Blurred Lines" Deposition (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/robin-thicke-admits-drug-abuse-732783|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=September 16, 2014|date=September 15, 2014}}</ref> Within Williams' respective deposition file, the producer noted that he was "in the driver's seat" during the song's creation and agreed that Thicke, in past interviews, "embellished" his contributions to the songwriting process.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gardner|first1=Eric|title=Robin Thicke Admits Drug Abuse, Lying to Media in Wild "Blurred Lines" Deposition (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/robin-thicke-admits-drug-abuse-732783|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=November 3, 2014|date=September 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Michaels|first1=Sean|title= Robin Thicke reportedly says he lied about co-writing Blurred Lines |url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/sep/16/robin-thicke-lied-co-written-blurred-lines-pharrell|website=The Guardian|accessdate=November 3, 2014}}</ref>
On October 30, 2014, [[United States District Court for the Central District of California]] Judge [[John A. Kronstadt]] ruled the Gaye family's lawsuit against Thicke and Williams could proceed, stating the plaintiffs "have made a sufficient showing that elements of 'Blurred Lines' may be substantially similar to protected, original elements of 'Got to Give It Up'." The trial began on February 10, 2015.<ref name=Kronstadt>{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Randy|title=Robin Thicke, Pharrell Williams lose first round in 'Blurred Lines' case|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-robin-thicke-pharrell-williams-blurred-lines-marvin-gaye-lawsuit-20141030-story.html|website=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=October 31, 2014|date=October 30, 2014}}</ref> Williams and Thicke filed a successful ''[[motion in limine]]'' to prevent a recording of "Got to Give it Up" from being played during the trial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/will-a-jury-get-hear-761443|title=Will a Jury Get to Hear Marvin Gaye Sing at the 'Blurred Lines' Trial Next Month?|date=January 6, 2015|first=Eriq|last=Gardner|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=March 11, 2015}}</ref><ref name="MIL">{{cite web|url=http://www.law360.com/articles/615345/marvin-gaye-recordings-barred-from-blurred-lines-trial|title=Marvin Gaye Recordings Barred From 'Blurred Lines' Trial|date=January 26, 2015|first=Brandon|last=Lowrey|website=Law360|accessdate=March 11, 2015}}</ref> The motion was granted because the family's copyright covered the sheet music and not necessarily other musical elements from Gaye's recording of the song. Judge Kronstad remarked: "I don't expect Marvin Gaye's voice to be part of this case."<ref name="MIL" />
On March 10, 2015, a jury found Thicke and Williams, but not T.I., liable for [[copyright infringement]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chelin|first1=Pamela|url=https://twitter.com/PamelaChelin/status/575407170151260160|title=Breaking: Thicke and Williams infringed copyright. Not T.I. Jury in favor of Gayes. More soon!|website=[[Twitter]]}}</ref> The unanimous jury awarded Gaye's family {{USD}}7.4 million in damages for copyright infringement.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2015/03/10/blurred-lines-trial-verdict/24492431/|title='Blurred Lines' jury finds for Marvin Gaye|author=Ann Oldenburg, USA TODAY|date=March 10, 2015|work=USA TODAY}}</ref> The response among some observers regarding the decision was that it was incorrect; bassist and entertainment law attorney [[Joe Escalante]] stated that the jury's verdict "must have been based on emotions because it is not based on any notions of what is protectable under copyright law today."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-blurred-lines-reaction-brian-wilson-bonnie-mckee-20150314-story.html#page=1 |title=Brian Wilson, Bonnie McKee and others react to 'Blurred Lines' verdict – LA Times |first= Randy|last= Lewis|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date= 2015-03-14|publisher=[[Tribune Co]] |location=[[Los Angeles, CA|Los Angeles]] |issn=0458-3035 |accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> Singer-songwriter [[Keith Urban]] said: "My initial reaction from it, I was shocked, honestly. Seems more like a sound and a feel and a style and a genre and an era, none of which can be copyrighted."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.people.com/article/blurred-lines-verdict-keith-urban-nick-lachey-react |title=Nick Lachey, Keith Urban Speak Out Against Blurred Lines Verdict|first= Kathy Erich|last= Dowd|work=people.com |date= 2015-03-14|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> Comedian and music parody artist [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] (who made a parody of the song with his 2014 "[[Word Crimes]]") described the ruling as "a raw deal", calling the song "Marvin Gaye [[pastiche]]."<ref>{{cite interview |last= Weird Al| interviewer=Brian Bingaman | title=Heading to the Mann Center July 31, "Weird Al" Yankovic talks about his multifaceted comedy|url=http://www.pottsmerc.com/arts-and-entertainment/20150723/heading-to-the-mann-center-july-31-weird-al-yankovic-talks-about-his-multifaceted-comedy|website=Pottsmerc.com|date= July 22, 2015|accessdate=12 October 2015}}</ref> Songwriter [[Burt Bacharach]] commented that "bad decisions were made" and that "the current situation was messy".<ref>{{cite interview | title=Burt Bacharach calls for change in music plagiarism law|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-40813002|website=BBC.com|date= August 3, 2017|accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> The verdict was also questioned by recording artists and musicians [[John Legend]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fekadu|first1=Mesfin|title=Q&A: John Legend on race, Common, Sam Smith, 'Blurred Lines'|url=https://news.yahoo.com/john-legend-blurred-lines-verdict-may-set-scary-205307456.html|website=yahoo.com|publisher=The Associated Press|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> [[Nile Rodgers]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Watson|first1=Sian|title=Nile Rodgers: 'Blurred Lines' court verdict 'shocking'|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/s/nile-rodgers-blurred-lines-court-verdict-shocking-200855358.html?nf=1|website=yahoo.com|publisher=The Associated Press|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> and [[Bill Withers]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mitchell|first1=Gail|title=Bill Withers Talks 'Blurred Lines' Verdict, Kardashian Family & More at ASCAP Expo|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6553786/bill-withers-talks-blurred-lines-verdict-kardashian-family-more-at-ascap-expo|website=Billboard.com|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> Classical music critic Mark Swed of the [[Los Angeles Times]] pointed out that many classical composers used material from previous composers saying that "[[John Williams]] all but lifted the core idea of his [[Star Wars (soundtrack)|Star Wars soundtrack score]] from the Scherzo of [[Erich Korngold]]'s [[Symphony in F-sharp major (Korngold)|Symphony in F-sharp Major]], written 25 years earlier."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-blurred-lines-classical-notebook-20150314-column.html |title='Blurred Lines' verdict would rock Amadeus and other great composers|first= Mark|last= Swed|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date= 2015-03-14|publisher=[[Tribune Co]] |location=[[Los Angeles, CA|Los Angeles]] |issn=0458-3035 |quote=Mark Swed |accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> However, [[Motown]] legend [[Smokey Robinson]] stated that it was a mistake to use the same melody, and that he thought it was "absolutely a rip off." <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CuYB6JNuDhE |title=Smokey Robinson on Howard Stern Show Full Interview 2015 |first=Elmer |last=Ferdinand |date=June 2, 2016 |publisher= |accessdate=August 24, 2016 |via=YouTube}}</ref>
In August 2016, Thicke, Williams, and T.I. appealed the judgment to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|9th Circuit Court of Appeals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/blurred-lines-creators-urge-appeals-922465|title="Blurred Lines" Creators Urge Appeals Court to Reverse Marvin Gaye Family's Trial Victory|last=Gardner|first=Eriq|date=August 24, 2016|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=|access-date=|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}</ref><ref name=RollingStoneAppeal>{{cite web|url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/pharrell-robin-thicke-ti-appeal-blurred-lines-verdict-w436116|title= Pharrell Williams, Robin Thicke, T.I. File Appeal Brief on 'Blurred Lines' Verdict|work=rollingstone.com|accessdate=1 September 2016|date= August 24, 2016|first= Althea|last= Legaspi}}</ref> Later that same month, more than 200 musicians – including among others [[Rivers Cuomo]] of [[Weezer]], [[John Oates]] of [[Hall & Oates]], [[R. Kelly]], [[Hans Zimmer]], [[Jennifer Hudson]] as well as members of [[Train (band)|Train]], [[Linkin Park]], [[Earth, Wind & Fire]], [[The Black Crowes]], [[Fall Out Boy]], [[The Go-Go's]] and [[Tears for Fears]] – filed an ''[[amicus curiae]]'' brief, authored by attorney Ed McPherson, in support of the appeal, stating that "the verdict in this case threatens to punish songwriters for creating new music that is inspired by prior works."<ref name=HollyRepAmicus>{{cite web|url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/blurred-lines-appeal-gets-support-924213|title="Blurred Lines" Appeal Gets Support From More Than 200 Musicians|first= Erig|last= Gardner|work=hollywoodreporter.com|date= August 30, 2016|access-date= September 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name="CBC News">CBC News: [http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/blurred-lines-appeal-musician-letter-1.3743751 More than 200 musicians support Blurred Lines appeal – Arts & Entertainment – CBC News]</ref> In March 2018, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's finding of infringement against Pharell Williams and Thicke.<ref name=Forbes2018/>
== Live performances == <!-- Commented out: [[File:Robin Thicke an Miley Cyrus performing at the 2013 MTV Video Music Awards.jpg|thumb|right|Thicke (''left'') performing "Blurred Lines" during the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]]. During the performance, [[Miley Cyrus]] (''right'') "[[Twerking|twerked]]" Thicke's crotch.|150px]] --> On May 14, 2013, Thicke performed the song for the first time live on NBC's ''[[The Voice (U.S. season 4)|The Voice]]'' alongside Pharrell and T.I. The website of ''[[Rap-Up]]'' magazine described Thicke as looking "dapper" in "black suit", and that the trio were joined on stage by "sexy ladies during the steamy set".<ref name="rap-up.com" /> Thicke also performed the song on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' on May 16 with Pharrell and three models doing backup.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Thicke performed the song live at the finale of ''[[Germany's Next Topmodel, Cycle 8]]'' on May 30, 2013, at [[SAP Arena]] in [[Mannheim]]. The performance featured the top 20 contestants of the cycle who danced to the song on chairs. The four finalists walked the [[Runway (fashion)|runway]] during the performance, as well as performing a [[American burlesque|burlesque]]-like dance on different items of furniture.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.directlyrics.com/watch-robin-thicke-psy-bruno-mars-perform-on-germanys-next-top-model-finale-news.html | title=Watch: Robin Thicke, Psy & Bruno Mars Perform on 'Germany's Next Top Model' Finale | publisher=[[Spin Media]] | work=''[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]'' | date=May 30, 2013 | accessdate=May 30, 2013}}</ref> On June 7, 2013, Thicke performed the song alongside Pharrell on the British television [[chat show]] ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hiphop-n-more.com/2013/06/robin-thicke-performs-blurred-lines-with-pharrell-on-the-graham-norton-show/ |title=Robin Thicke Performs 'Blurred Lines' With Pharrell On 'The Graham Norton Show'|date=June 8, 2013|work=Hiphop-n-more|accessdate=June 11, 2013 }}</ref> He also performed the song (with recorded T.I. and Pharrell backing vocals) on ''[[The Voice Australia]]'' season 2 finale on June 17, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9AqTt2GTH-Q|title='Blurred Lines' – Robin Thicke performs live on The Voice (Australia)(video)|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> Thicke performed the song on the [[BET Awards 2013|2013 BET Awards]] on June 30, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-awards/2013/performers/robin-thicke.html|title=Robin Thicke|publisher=[[BET Awards 2013]]|accessdate=9 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806032324/http://www.bet.com/shows/bet-awards/2013/performers/robin-thicke.html|archivedate=August 6, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Thicke also performed the track solo on [[Great Britain|British]] morning TV show ''[[Lorraine (TV programme)|Lorraine]]'' and [[BBC Radio 1]] [[Live Lounge]] on July 8, 2013, as well as ''[[This Morning (TV programme)|This Morning]]'' on July 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h4HLrT00dA4|title=Robin Thicke - Blurred Lines in the Live Lounge|publisher=BBC Radio One on YouTube|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://idolator.com/7470104/robin-thicke-blurred-lines-this-morning-watch|title=Robin Thicke Performs "Blurred Lines" on 'This Morning':watch|publisher=idolator.com|accessdate=10 August 2013}}</ref> Thicke also performed the song complete with dancers in studio on ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' on [[Sirius XM Radio]] July 29, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/news/robin-thicke-performs-blurred-lines-in-studio-69|title=Robin Thicke performs "Blurred Lines" in Studio 69|publisher=howardstern.com|accessdate=9 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801082431/http://www.howardstern.com/news/robin-thicke-performs-blurred-lines-in-studio-69|archivedate=August 1, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He also performed the song on ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' on August 6, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2013/08/08/robin-thicke-blurred-lines-colbert-report/|title=Watch Robin Thicke Perform "Blurred LInes" on The Colbert Report|publisher=highsnobiety.com|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> On September 20, he performed Blurred Lines at the 2013 [[iHeartRadio Music Festival]]. On November 10, Thicke performed the song with [[Iggy Azalea]] at the [[2013 MTV Europe Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Robin Thicke Performs with Iggy Azalea at MTV EMA|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/11/10/video-robin-thicke-performs-with-iggy-azalea-at-mtv-ema/|work=[[Rap-Up]]|accessdate=November 11, 2013|date=November 10, 2013}}</ref> In December, he performed the song at Jingle Ball 2013 concerts. In May 2014, Williams performed the song as part of a medley at the iHeartRadio Awards where he received the iHeartRadio Innovator Award.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fekadu|first=Mesfin|title=Tears of joy: Pharrell 'happy' at awards show|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/music/20140501_ap_183a1bf702df42f28a5dfe64ad067df2.html|publisher=Philly.com|accessdate=May 4, 2014|date=May 1, 2014}}</ref> In May 2017, He performed the song at [[4th Indonesian Choice Awards]].
=== MTV Video Music Awards === Thicke performed Blurred Lines as a duet with [[Miley Cyrus]] at the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]], medleyed with Cyrus' "[[We Can't Stop]]" and "[[Give It 2 U]]", featuring [[2 Chainz]]. The performance began with Cyrus performing "We Can't Stop" in bear-themed attire. Following this, Thicke entered the stage and Cyrus stripped down to a small skin-colored two-piece outfit. Cyrus subsequently touched Thicke's crotch area with a giant foam finger and [[Twerking|twerked]] against his crotch.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2402415/Miley-Cyrus-VMAs-Parents-label-Miley-Cyrus-creepy-VMA-performance-sexual-exploitation-20-year-old-desperately-tried-shed-wholesome-Disney-image.html|title=Parents' fury at Miley Cyrus' VMA performance as she desperately tried (and succeeded) to shed her wholesome Disney image by simulating sex acts with a foam finger|date=August 26, 2013|newspaper=Daily Mail|publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust|accessdate=August 27, 2013|location=London}}</ref> The performance drew extensive reactions and became the most tweeted about event in history, with [[Twitter]] users generating 360,000 tweets about the event per minute; breaking the previous record held by [[Beyoncé]]'s [[Super Bowl XLVII halftime show]] performance six months earlier.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/vmas-2013-celebs-react-miley-cyrus-robin-thicke-performance-article-1.1437027 | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=VMAs 2013: Miley Cyrus, Robin Thicke performance draws negative reactions from fellow celebrities – NY Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1713119/vma-ratings-record.jhtml |title=Thanks Miley! 2013 VMAs Shatter Twitter Records |work=MTV |accessdate=August 24, 2016}}</ref>
== In popular culture == An ad was created for [[Radio Shack]] to market the [[Beats Pill (portable speaker)|Beats Pill]], a small stereo, that showed Thicke, Pharrell, and the models repeating the look of the (clothed) music video, but with the models holding up the Beats Pill.<ref>{{cite news |title=RadioShack 'Beats By Dr. Dre Pill' Ad: Phallic Imagery, Half-Naked Women And Robin Thicke (VIDEO) |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/08/radio-shack-beats-by-dr-dre-pill-ad_n_3238229.html |date=May 8, 2013 |publisher=''The Huffington Post'' |first=Ron |last=Dicker}}</ref>
A cover featuring Thicke himself with classroom instruments was performed by [[Jimmy Fallon]] and [[The Roots]], with [[Black Thought]] filling in for T.I.'s verse.<ref name="Classroom instruments">{{YouTube|YOZjaqHioro|Jimmy Fallon, Robin Thicke & The Roots Sing "Blurred Lines" (w/ Classroom Instruments) }} (uploaded Aug 1, 2013)</ref>
=== Parodies === On June 12, 2013 episode of ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', in which Thicke and Pharrell were both guests, they aired a parody version of the "Blurred Lines" video in which host [[Jimmy Kimmel]] and his sidekick [[Guillermo Rodriguez (Jimmy Kimmel Live!)|Guillermo]] attempt to join Thicke, Pharrell, and the dancers but keep getting rebuffed. The parody video was also placed on [[YouTube]], and received over 2 million views in less than a month.<ref>{{YouTube|NTqmiwHHktE|Jimmy Kimmel and Guillermo in "Blurred Lines" (feat. Robin Thicke and Pharrell)}} (uploaded June 13, 2013)</ref>
On June 30, 2013 [[Remy Munasifi]] released a parody on his GoRemy YouTube channel entitled "Blurred Lines: The Anthony Weiner version" mocking Anthony Weiner's entry into the [[Anthony Weiner sexting scandals#2013 mayoral race and second scandal|2013 New York City mayoral elections]].<ref>{{YouTube|NUYqc5m9Exk}}</ref>
On July 30, 2013 A gender swapped parody video was created for the ''[[Nikki and sara live|Nikki and Sara Live]]'' show airing during the season two premiere, featuring the hostesses of the show being increasingly weirded out by naked male dancers and the unusual barnyard theme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/?series=2215&seriesId=39474&channelId=1&id=1711513|title=Nikki & Sara LIVE – Blurred Lines|work=MTV}}</ref>
On August 2, 2013 [[Bart Baker]] released a parody of "Blurred Lines" on his YouTube channel. It currently has over 45 million views.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J3twwafch4g|title=Robin Thicke - "Blurred Lines" PARODY|first=Bart |last=Baker |date=August 2, 2013 |publisher=|accessdate=August 24, 2016 |via=YouTube}}</ref>
On August 31, 2013, [[The University of Auckland]]'s Law Revue produced a feminist inspired parody called "Defined Lines". The video received over 290,000 views in its first weekend on YouTube before being temporarily removed due to sexual content.<ref>{{YouTube|tC1XtnLRLPM|Robin Thicke – Blurred Lines [Feminist Parody] "Defined Lines"}}</ref> It was subsequently reinstated a couple of days later, with YouTube owner Google admitting it 'made a mistake'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/music/9119939/YouTube-reinstates-Defined-Lines|title=YouTube reinstates Defined Lines|author=Liam Hyslop|publisher=Fairfax Media NZ|date=2013-09-03}}</ref>
On September 11, 2013, the drag queen group DWV ([[Detox (drag queen)|Detox]], [[Willam Belli]], and Vicky Vox), released a parody called "Blurred Bynes." The song is about [[Amanda Bynes]] and her behavior in the previous months.<ref>{{YouTube|mr51afj7eJY|Blurred Bynes by DWV (Detox, Willam & Vicky Vox)}}</ref>
On September 26, 2013, [[Yuko Oshima]] and [[Haruna Kojima]] of Japanese idol group [[AKB48]] were featured in a parody video, together with Thicke and some of the original video's members to raise the profile of AKB48 in America while raising Thicke's profile in Japan.<ref>{{YouTube|VlwyKjlaxf0|ロビン・シック×AKB48「ブラード・ラインズ～今夜はヘイ・ヘイ・ヘイ♪」}}</ref>
On November 5, 2013, [[Dave Callan]], as part of his review of [[Just Dance 2014]] on the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] show [[Good Game (television series)|Good Game]] performed a parody of the music video in response to the incorrect choreography of the song in the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TskRX86dIX0 |title=Dave Callan's Bearded Lines|publisher=[[ABC2|ABC]]: [[Good Game (television series)|Good Game]], Episode 39 Season 9|accessdate=9 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQ3YDhhrLPw |title=Good Game Episode 39 Season 9|publisher=[[ABC2|ABC]]: [[Good Game (television series)|Good Game]] |accessdate=9 November 2013}}</ref>
On December 19, 2013, the Canadian sketch comedy group [[Royal Canadian Air Farce]] released a parody of the music video called "Rob Ford's Blurred Lines" highlighting the recent admissions by [[Toronto]] mayor [[Rob Ford]] of public drunkenness and using crack cocaine.<ref>{{YouTube|Lbj2T6oPxUc}}</ref>
In their reunion show transmitted on 26 May 2014, the cast of [[Goodness Gracious Me (BBC)|Goodness Gracious Me Special 2014]] performed a parody of the song and video entitled "No Blurred Lines". The video begins with the three male leads being shown under on-screen labels of "#Thicke", "#Thicker" and "#Thickest" ('thick' being British slang for 'stupid'). The lyrics make fun of the stereotype of the rowdy male Asian-Indian teenage boy. As pointed to by its title, the lyrics also mock and refute the sexist attitudes of the original song.
[[Rucka Rucka Ali]] has created his own parody, entitled "Obama Been Watching" which satirizes, among other things, the [[NSA]] and [[Edward Snowden]].
On July 15, 2014, [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] released a parody of the song entitled "[[Word Crimes]]" from his album ''[[Mandatory Fun]]''.<ref name=sticker>{{cite web|title=CD Promo Sticker|url=http://i.imgur.com/bEKk0cN.jpg|accessdate=July 10, 2014|date=July 10, 2014}}</ref> The music video was released online the same day.<ref name="rs word crimes">{{cite web | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/weird-al-shows-off-big-dictionary-in-robin-thicke-parody-word-crimes-20140715 | title = Weird Al Shows Off Big Dictionary in Robin Thicke Parody 'Word Crimes' | first = Jon | last = Blisten | date = July 15, 2014 | accessdate = July 15, 2014 | work = [[Rolling Stone]] }}</ref><ref>{{youtube|8Gv0H-vPoDc|"Weird Al" Yankovic - Word Crimes}}</ref>
On September 24, 2014, Glove and Boots, a production of [[Bento Box Entertainment]], published a comedic recap of the legal dispute in the form of a music video parody entitled "A Brief History of Robin Thicke's 2013 Summer Hit".<ref>{{cite web|title=A Brief History of Robin Thicke's 2013 Summer Hit | url=http://www.gloveandboots.com/?p=348 | accessdate=September 24, 2014 | date=September 24, 2014}}</ref>
[[Cledus T. Judd]], who is primarily a country music parodist, released a parody in November 2014 titled "[[Luke Bryan]]", which features guest vocals from [[Colt Ford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2014/11/cledus-t-judd-releases-new-parody-single-luke-bryan/|title=Cledus T. Judd Releases New Parody Single "Luke Bryan"|last=Stephenson|first=Troy|date=6 November 2014|work=[[MusicRow]]|accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref>
=== Media === In Chile, the song was used on [[Via X]]'s TV show ''Super Bueno'' and [[Zona Latina]]'s ''No eres tu soy yo''; it was also included in the soundtrack of TV soap opera ''[[Somos Los Carmona]]'', and was featured on TV adverts from Chilean department store chain [[La Polar]].
The song appears in the video games [[NBA 2K14]] and [[Just Dance 2014]].
On July 23, 2013, the [[YouTube]] channel [[Barack's Dubs]] uploaded a mashup video of former [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Bill Clinton]] singing the song.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hU3CYs77Ku4|title=Bill Clinton Singing Blurred Lines by Robin Thicke|date=23 July 2013|work=YouTube}}</ref>
The song was featured in both the TV ads and theatrical trailer for the 2013 film ''[[The Best Man Holiday]]''.
The song was featured in an episode of the [[Two and a Half Men (season 11)|11th season]] of the hit [[CBS]] sitcom ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'', sang by the character Walden Schmidt (played by [[Ashton Kutcher]]).
It has been used as the first song on several radio stations flipping to CHR or similar formats, most recently on March 31, 2014, when [[CKZZ-FM]] in Vancouver, BC, Canada, rebranded from ''Virgin Radio 95.3'' back to their original name as ''Z95.3''.
In Poland, the song was used on ''[[Taniec z Gwiazdami (season 15)|Taniec z Gwiazdami]]'' (Polish version of ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' format) [[Taniec z Gwiazdami (season 15)|15th season]]'s trailer in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jastrzabpost.pl/newsy/spot-tanca-gwiazdami-rytmie-przeboju-blurred-lines-zobacz-sie-prezentuja-pary-wideo_32734.html|title=SPOT "TAŃCA Z GWIAZDAMI" W RYTMIE PRZEBOJU "BLURRED LINES"! ZOBACZ, JAK SIĘ PREZENTUJĄ PARY [WIDEO]|date=September 2, 2014|accessdate=January 5, 2015|language=pl}}</ref>
The song was played before the end of the special episode of ''[[Eat Bulaga!]]'' entitled ''Sa Tamang Panahon'' performed by [[Jose Manalo]] as Frankie with thanking the sponsors in October 24, 2015 at the [[Philippine Arena]].
In Albania contestant Kastro imitated Robin on the Albanian version of [[Your Face Sounds Familiar (Albanian TV Series)]]
=== Covers === The bands [[Queens of the Stone Age]], [[Vampire Weekend]] and [[The Mend (band)|The Mend]] have performed cover versions of the song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/queens-of-the-stone-age/70798|title=NME News Queens Of The Stone Age cover Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' – watch – NME.COM|date=June 11, 2013|work=NME.COM}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2013/07/23/vampire-weekend-blurred-lines-robin-thicke-cover/|title=New Song: Vampire Weekend, 'Blurred Lines' (Robin Thicke Cover)|work=Buzzworthy}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|Krvk8f6AhdA|The Mend perform Blurred Lines}}. Retrieved 28th October 2013</ref>
The song was covered in the ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' episode "[[The End of Twerk]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s/qid=1327094181/ref=sr_st?redirect=true&field-keywords=Glee+Cast&search-alias=digital-music&rd=1&sort=-releasedate|title=Glee Cast – MP3 downloads|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=November 5, 2013}}</ref> which aired on November 14, 2013 by the show's main characters [[Will Schuester]] ([[Matthew Morrison]]) and the members of [[Glee (TV series)|New Directions]].
The song was also performed by the [[Tusker Project Fame]] season 6 Contestants in their eighth week.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
[[Rockabye Baby!]] released a [[lullaby]] cover of the song.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
