page.title: Fukuoka Municipal Zoo and Botanical Garden

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fukuoka (city)]] to [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fukuoka]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox zoo |zoo_name = Fukuoka Municipal Zoo and Botanical Garden |logo = |logo_caption = |image = Fukuoka zoo entrance.jpg |image_caption = Zoo entrance |location = [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka]], [[Japan]] |date_opened = 1933
1953 (in current location) |date_closed = |coordinates = {{Coord|33.572261|130.390424|type:landmark|display=it}} |area = |num_species = |num_animals = |largest_tank_vol = |total_tank_vol = |annual_visitors = |members = [[Japanese Association of Zoos and Aquariums|JAZA]], [[Botanic Gardens Conservation International|BGCI]] |exhibits = |website = [http://zoo.city.fukuoka.jp/ zoo.city.fukuoka.jp] }} [[Image:Tsushima Cat 001.jpg|thumb|left|180px|[[Tsushima cat]] bred at the Fukuoka Zoo]] The {{nihongo|'''Fukuoka Municipal Zoo and Botanical Garden'''|福岡市動植物園|Fukuoka-shi Dōshokubutsuen}}, also known as the '''Fukuoka City Zoological Garden''', is a [[zoo]] and [[botanical garden]] established in 1953 and located within Minami-koen (''En'': "South park") at 1-1, Minami-Koen, [[Chūō-ku, Fukuoka|Chūō-ku]], [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka]], [[Japan]]. The garden contains about 1,300 types of outdoor garden plants, mostly common. Its greenhouse contains over 1,200 plant species including [[orchid]]s, [[fern]]s, and [[cactus|cacti]]. ==History== [[Image:PC130044.JPG|thumb|right|270px|A [[Malayan sun bear]] from Fukuoka Zoo]] The gardens were originally established near the city's East park in 1933 as part of the celebration of the coronation of Emperor [[Hirohito]]. This small {{Convert|5096|tsubo|ha|sing=on}} zoo and botanical garden included about 500 animals and 100 species of plants. The zoo was closed to the public on 20 May 1944 due to the deteriorating state of [[World War II]] for the country. Large animals were subsequently euthanized. Pillars from the old zoo gate are still standing near one of the elementary schools in the city. In 1949 the city approved the establishment of a zoo in the city's South park. The Fukuoka City Zoological Society was established in 1952, and {{yen}}28 million was raised for the new zoo. The zoo opened in its current location on 22 August 1953, with 143 animals representing 69 species. It included a play area with a miniature train and a Ferris wheel. When it opened, the zoo was home to one elephant, who was still living at the zoo in 2011. In 1954 the zoo was expanded to the North by about {{Convert|6500|tsubo|sing=on}}, and the animal collection expanded to include 353 individuals representing 110 species. In 1955 the zoo was transferred to the jurisdiction of the Jurisdiction of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Tourism Division, Fukuoka. An additional {{Convert|6|ha}} was added to the zoo in 1956, and the animal collection again expanded to include 400 individuals of 120 species. By 2003 (the fiftieth anniversary of opening in its current location), the zoo had hosted more than 40 million visitors, and was home to 706 animals representing 168 species, including 57 species of mammals, 88 species of birds, and 23 species of reptiles. == See also == * [[List of botanical gardens in Japan]] ==Notes== {{Reflist |refs= {{Cite web |url=http://zoo.city.fukuoka.lg.jp/sougou/index.php?history=index |title=Pre-history of the zoo |work=zoo.city.fukuoka.lg.jp |publisher=Fukuoka Municipal Zoo and Botanical Garden |accessdate=23 September 2011 }} {{Cite web |url=http://zoo.city.fukuoka.lg.jp/sougou/index.php?history=01 |title=History of the second phase of the zoo |work=zoo.city.fukuoka.lg.jp |publisher=Fukuoka Municipal Zoo and Botanical Garden |accessdate=23 September 2011 }} {{Cite web |url=http://zoo.city.fukuoka.lg.jp/sougou/index.php?history=05b |title=History of the Fukuoka Municipal Zoo (Phase 5 Part 2) |work=zoo.city.fukuoka.lg.jp |publisher=Fukuoka Municipal Zoo and Botanical Garden |accessdate=231 September 2011 }} {{ZooOrg|jaza|zoos|accessdate=21 September 2011}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.bgci.org/garden.php?id=1500&ftrCountry=JP&ftrKeyword=&ftrBGCImem=&ftrIAReg |title=Fukuoka Municipal Botanical Garden |work=bgci.org |publisher=[[Botanic Gardens Conservation International|BGCI]] |accessdate=21 September 2011 }} {{Cite web |url=http://www.fukuoka-now.com/articles/show/1016 |title=Fukuoka Municipal Zoo & Botanical Garden |work=fukuoka-now.com |publisher=Fukuoka Now Magazine |accessdate=21 September 2011 }} {{Cite web |url=http://www.elephant.se/location2.php?location_id=1397 |title=Fukuoka Zoo in Japan |work=elephant.se |publisher=Elephant Encyclopedia |accessdate=22 September 2011 }} }} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline|Fukuoka City Zoological Garden}} *{{Official website|http://zoo.city.fukuoka.jp/}} (Japanese) {{DEFAULTSORT:Fukuoka Municipal Zoo And Botanical Garden}} [[Category:Botanical gardens in Japan]] [[Category:Zoos in Japan]] [[Category:Gardens in Fukuoka Prefecture]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fukuoka]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fukuoka]] [[Category:Zoos established in 1953]] [[Category:1953 establishments in Japan]]

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2007}}
'''Generic characters''' are interchangeable characters, appearing mostly in [[Animated series|animated shows]] or [[comic strips]]. They often reappear at different times with different jobs, or are seen in the background. Animation or comic strip artists, when in need of a character who furthers the story without becoming part of it, often use an existing character from their repertoire instead of inventing a new one. Generics can be considered to be similar to [[gag characters]], but might stay longer.
==See also== *[[Cartoon character]] *[[Unseen Characters]] *[[Osamu Tezuka's Star System]]
==External links== *[http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGenericGuy TvTropes: The Generic Guy]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Generic Character (Fiction)}} [[Category:Fictional characters by role in the narrative structure]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2017}} {{italic title}} <!-- {{Redirect6|Hot Coffee|the beverage|coffee|the lawsuit over a hot coffee burn|Liebeck v. McDonald's Restaurants}} --> {{Infobox video game | title = ''Hot Coffee'' mod | italic title = no | image = Hot coffee.png | caption = A screenshot of ''GTA: San Andreas'' with the ''Hot Coffee'' mod | developer = [[Rockstar North]] | publisher = [[Rockstar Games]] | designer = Patrick Wildenborg | series = ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' | engine = | released = See ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'' | genre = | modes = | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] }}
'''''Hot Coffee''''' is a normally inaccessible [[mini-game]] in the 2004 [[video game]] ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'', developed by [[Rockstar North]]. Public awareness of the existence of the mini-game arrived with the release of the ''Hot Coffee'' [[Mod (computer gaming)|mod]], created for the [[Microsoft Windows]] port of ''GTA: San Andreas'' in 2005. This mod enables access to the mini-game.
The mini-game portrays animated [[sexual intercourse]] between the main character, [[Carl "CJ" Johnson]], and his chosen in-game [[girlfriend]]. The name of the mod is derived from the girlfriend's offer for the main character to come into her home for "coffee", a euphemism for sex.
Although the "Hot Coffee" mini-game was completely disabled and its existence was only highlighted after the mod's release for the PC version on June 9, 2005,<ref name=ModRelease>{{cite web | url = http://patrickw.gtagames.nl/mods.html | title = Hot Coffee mod developer's mod listing | work = PatrickW's modding website | accessdate = July 5, 2006}}</ref> the assets for the mini-game were also discovered in both the [[PlayStation 2]] and [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] versions of the game, and people found ways to enable the mini-game via console video game hacking tools. By the middle of July 2005, the mini-game's discovery attracted considerable [[Video game controversy|controversy]] from lawmakers and politicians, prompting the game to be re-assessed with an "[[List of AO-rated video games|Adults Only (AO)]]" [[Video game ratings system|rating]] by the U.S. [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] (ESRB), and refused classification in Australia, resulting in its removal from sale.
An updated version of ''San Andreas'' has since been released with the mini-game removed completely, allowing the game to regain its original rating. A [[Patch (computing)|patch]] for the original version of the game, Cold Coffee, was designed to counter edit the script and disable the mini-game and crash the game if one attempts to access it.<ref name=nomoarcoffee>{{cite web | url = http://www.nomorehotcoffee.com/ | title = No More Hot Coffee | work = [[Rockstar Games]] | accessdate = 15 September 2016}}</ref>
== Minigame overview and ''Hot Coffee'' mod == {{Tone|date=November 2008}} Throughout the game, [[Carl "CJ" Johnson]], the game's protagonist, may date up to six [[girlfriend]]s, carrying out various "date missions" in order to improve his relationship with a particular woman. Once CJ has become particularly close to a girlfriend, or if he has collected all oysters in the game, his girlfriend may end a successful date by inviting him into her house for "coffee," from which CJ may choose to accept or decline. Improving relationships with girlfriends through successful dates and other related activities will eventually reward CJ with new items, such as vehicles and special wardrobes, along with pre-existing gameplay benefits (e.g. dating a nurse grants CJ with free visits to the hospital without losing his weapons after dying).
In the unmodified version of ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'', players see an exterior view of the girlfriend's house while muffled voices of CJ and his girlfriend engaging in [[sexual intercourse]] are heard. However, the ''Hot Coffee'' mod replaces this with a minigame which allows the player to actually enter the girlfriend's bedroom and control Carl's actions during sex, with the same controls as dancing.
[[Rockstar Games]], the publisher of the ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' series, initially denied allegations that the mini-game was "hidden" in the video game, stating that the ''Hot Coffee'' modification (which they claim violated the game's [[software license|End User License Agreement]]) is the result of "[[Hacker (computer security)|hackers]]" making "significant technical modifications to and [[reverse engineering]]" the game's code.<ref name=baertlein>{{cite web | url = https://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/nm/20050714/us_nm/media_grandtheftauto_dc_2 | title = 'Grand Theft' maker blames hackers for sex scenes | work = [[Reuters]] | accessdate = 13 July 2005 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20050305201757/http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story | archive-date = 2005-03-05 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> However, this claim was undermined when a user known as '''gothi''' from the website '''PS2 Save Tools''' released the "GTA:SA Censor Remover" tool for the [[PlayStation 2]] and [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] versions in June 2005, which allowed the minigame to be accessed on consoles. These new methods of accessing "Hot Coffee" demonstrated that the controversial content was, indeed, built into the console versions as well.
The PC mod itself is only an edited copy of the main game script file ("main.scm") with a single [[bit]] changed. The mod was also made possible on the console versions by changing the bit inside a user's saved game file or by using a third-party modding device. Take-Two has stated that the mod constitutes a violation of the End User License Agreement,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20051017024339/http://ir.take2games.com/ReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=169278 Take-Two Games - Investor Relations General Information]</ref> even though modification of the main.scm file is common within the mod community.
However, the oral sex animations are clearly visible in the background during one scene of the mission "Cleaning the Hood", even in the re-released game.<ref name="Norway">{{cite web | url = http://pub.tv2.no/nettavisen/it/article432538.ece | title = Nye sex-avsløringer i drapsspill |trans-title=New sex revelations in murder game | work = [[Nettavisen]] | date = 5 August 2005 | language = Norwegian | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160416042146/http://pub.nettavisen.no/432538.html | archivedate = 16 April 2016}}</ref> This may explain why the minigame was not simply removed when the decision was made to cut it from the game; its assets were already in use elsewhere.<ref name="romblog">{{cite web | url = http://www.romsteady.net/blog/2005/07/my-take-on-hot-coffee.html | title = My Take On "Hot Coffee" | work = Rom's Rants | accessdate = 14 June 2006}}</ref>
== Controversy == {{wikinewspar2|Video game's secret sex scenes spark outrage|Grand Theft Auto under fire}} The revelation of the mini-game sparked a fair amount of controversy around ''Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas'', with some politicians firing harsh words at both the game's developer and the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] (ESRB), the organization which establishes content ratings for video games in North America. It also rekindled the debate over the influence of video games in general with new protests against several other games such as ''[[Killer7]]'', ''[[The Sims 2]]'', and ''[[Bully (video game)|Bully]]''.
[[Jack Thompson (activist)|Jack Thompson]] was one of the first to criticize the game for its hidden content, believing violent media is one of the main causes of violent crime in America. Thompson lashed out against [[Rockstar Games]] on several occasions for previous games they have developed.
[[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Hillary Clinton]] suggested that new regulations be put on video games sales.<ref name="feldman">{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/news/2005/07/14/news_6129040.html | title = Clinton calls for federal game regulation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050721031345/http://www.gamespot.com/news/2005/07/14/news_6129040.html |archivedate=21 July 2005 | work = [[GameSpot]] | accessdate = 14 July 2005}}</ref> The [[ESRB]] conducted an investigation that ultimately changed the game's rating from Mature to Adults Only 18+.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bowles |first=Scott |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/products/games/2005-07-20-gta-sex_x.htm |title='Grand Theft Auto' gets pulled over - USA Today July 20, 2005 |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2005-07-21 |accessdate=2014-05-20}}</ref> Also, Congress passed a resolution to have the [[Federal Trade Commission]] investigate whether Rockstar intentionally undermined the ESRB by having the content in the game.<ref name="feldman2">{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/ps2/action/gta4/news_6129836.html | title = Take-Two sued, confirms FTC investigation | work = [[GameSpot]] | accessdate = 27 July 2005}}</ref>
In New York, a [[class action lawsuit]] was filed by Florence Cohen, an 85-year-old grandmother who purchased the game for her 14-year-old grandson (according to the old rating of "M", the game is typically considered inappropriate for this age). Cohen's lawsuit claimed that Rockstar Games and [[Take-Two Interactive]], the publisher of the game, are guilty of [[deception]], [[false advertising]], [[fraud]] and [[abuse]]. The accusation of deception is based on the change from M-rated to AO, meaning according to the lawsuit that the original rating was a deceptive practice.<ref name="berardini">{{cite web | url = http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/8839/Grandma-Sues-Rockstar-Over-San-Andreas/ | title = Grandma Sues Rockstar Over San Andreas | work = [[TeamXbox]] | accessdate = 27 July 2005 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050730024832/http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/8839/Grandma-Sues-Rockstar-Over-San-Andreas/ | archivedate = 30 July 2005 | df = }}</ref>
A protest group known as the Peaceholics organized a protest on August 4, 2005 at Rockstar's headquarters. The group demonstrated against ''San Andreas'' as well as the game ''[[Bully (video game)|Bully]]'', the latter due to fears that the content could inspire children to become bullies themselves.<ref name="ransom">{{cite web | url = http://www.joystiq.com/entry/1234000070053157/ | title = March against Bully | work = [[Joystiq]] | accessdate = 4 August 2005}}</ref><ref name="crecente">{{cite web | url = http://kotaku.com/gaming/rockstar/group-releases-rockstar-demands-115751.php | title = Group Releases Rockstar Demands | work = [[Joystiq]] | accessdate = 4 August 2005 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051125164311/http://www.kotaku.com/gaming/rockstar/group-releases-rockstar-demands-115751.php | archivedate = 25 November 2005 | df = }}</ref>
== Response ==
=== Product re-rating === On July 8, 2005, the [[ESRB]] announced that it was aware of and opening an investigation into the circumstances surrounding 'Hot Coffee.' The investigation examined "whether the mod unlocks preexisting code...or is actually a purely third-party creation."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/esrb-to-investigate-san-andreas-sex-content/2100-1043_3-5780374.html |title=ESRB to investigate San Andreas sex content |publisher=CNET Networks |work=CNET |date=2005-07-08 |accessdate=2014-05-20}}</ref>
On July 20, 2005, the [[ESRB]] announced that it was changing the rating of ''GTA:SA'' from ''Mature'' (M) to ''Adults Only'' (AO), making this the first and only ''Grand Theft Auto'' game to receive an AO Rating.<ref name="RerateToAORating">{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/news/6129500.html | title = San Andreas rated AO, Take-Two suspends production | work = [[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CNET Networks]] | accessdate = July 1, 2006}}</ref> Rockstar stated that it would discontinue manufacturing the current version of the game, and produce a new version that would not include the content that is unlocked by the Hot Coffee mod. In the fourth quarter of 2005, Rockstar released this "clean" version with the "Hot Coffee" scenes removed (''Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas'' 1.01), allowing the rating of the game to be reverted to its original ''Mature'' rating.<ref name="RevertToMRating">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6152490.html |title=FTC Hot Coffee ruling scalds, but doesn't burn Take-Two |work=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=CNET Networks |accessdate=July 1, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060708231006/http://www.gamespot.com/news/6152490.html |archivedate=July 8, 2006 |df= }}</ref>
On July 29, 2005, as a result of the newly discovered scenes, the Australian [[Office of Film and Literature Classification (Australia)|Office of Film and Literature Classification]] (OFLC) revoked the game's "MA15+" classification (the highest rating then available for computer games in Australia) and changed the game's rating to ''Refused Classification'' (RC), which officially banned the original version from being sold in the country. The patched version was given an "MA15+" classification on September 12, 2005.<ref>[http://www.oflc.gov.au/special.html?n=46&p=156&sTitle=San+Andreas&sMediaFilm=1&sMediaPublications=1&sMediaGames=1&sDateFromM=1&sDateFromY=1970&sDateToM=7&sDateToY=2006&record=207350 The Classification Board and Classification Review Board<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On August 10, 2005, Rockstar Games officially released a patch for ''San Andreas''.<ref name="nomorehotcoffee">{{cite web | url = http://www.nomorehotcoffee.com/ | title = No More Hot Coffee | work = [[Rockstar Games]] patch website | accessdate = 14 June 2006}}</ref> The patch fixed many performance issues and bugs. However, the patch also disabled the controversial "Hot Coffee" scenes, even if the "Hot Coffee" mod was re-installed.
There was little reaction in [[Europe]]. The game was already rated "18+" by [[Pan European Game Information|PEGI]] prior to the release of the mod. Furthermore, PEGI ratings are enforced by law in many European nations, making it a criminal offense to sell 18+ games to minors. In the United Kingdom, the [[BBFC]] similarly gave the game an "18" rating (as of 2012, the BBFC no longer classifies video games, and PEGI was adopted instead).
=== Product withdrawal and recall === {{Wikinews|Stores drop game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas" after given 'Adults Only' rating}} The day after the rating change, several [[North America]]n chain stores, and [[Interactive Entertainment Merchants Association|IEMA]] retailers, which accounted for every major retailer in the [[United States]] and approximately 85% of the game's market in the country, removed the PC and console versions of the game from their store shelves, re-stickered the box with the new rating, or returning it to Take-Two Interactive. These included major chains such as [[GameStop]], [[Sears Holdings Corporation|Sears]], [[Hudson's Bay Company]], [[Zellers]], [[Hollywood Video]], [[Blockbuster (movie rental store)|Blockbuster]], [[Wal-Mart]], [[Target Corporation|Target]], [[Best Buy]], and [[Electronics Boutique]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2005/07/20/technology/personaltech/gta/|title=Wal-Mart and Target Pull ''Grand Theft Auto''|author=Chris Morris|publisher=[[CNN Money]]|date=20 July 2005|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> Rockstar gave some retailers ESRB "Adults Only" rating stickers to put on their copies of ''GTA:SA'', should they decide to keep selling the original product.
[[eBay]] removed copies of ''GTA:SA'' that had been reported by the eBay community. eBay claimed that ''GTA:SA'' violated the terms of the eBay seller policy and could not be sold unless it was located in the ''Everything Else > Mature Audiences'' section. This section requires a credit card to validate the age of the eBay user. {{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
On August 24, 2005, Rockstar announced a mandatory [[Product recall|recall]] for all games still owned by the general public.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Consumers who had already purchased the game were allowed to keep it in certain areas, but with the patch installed, although players cannot be forced to return (or destroy) existing copies. Given the higher value of the "uncensored" versions, it is doubtful that many gamers will return their copies voluntarily. However, those who were over 18 (or 21 depending on region) have [[grandfather clause|grandfathered]] these copies of the game to their collection.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}}
Version 2.0 of ''GTA:SA'', which omitted the sexual mini-game content, was designed by Rockstar to crash if the game data files were modified. This made it necessary for players to use a previous version if they wished to install multiplayer game [[Mod (computer gaming)|modification]]s such as ''San Andreas Multiplayer'' or ''[[Multi Theft Auto]]'' and other game modifications that include new scripts or vehicles. Certain [[Copyright infringement of software|pirated or illegally distributed]] versions of the original game may also be made available on the Internet or from illegal retail outlets. Downgraders are also available to unpatch and revert the game version and support the Hot Coffee mini-game again.
This limitation later was overcome<ref>{{cite web|title = GTA modding |url=http://www.gtamodding.com/index.php?title=San_Andreas_v2.0_Modding |accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref> by two members of the unofficial ''Grand Theft Auto'' [[Grand Theft Auto modding|modding]] community, who discovered a method of creating modifications which would work with version 2.0. Users of version 2.0 might still need to use previous versions or use a downgrade in order to install a mod not created with the new method.
=== Federal and legal action === [[File:Hillary Clinton official Secretary of State portrait crop.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Hillary Clinton was featured in ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'' where the Statue of Happiness has her face and holds a coffee cup. This is an allusion to her role in the controversy.]] In December 2005, Senators [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Joe Lieberman]] and [[Evan Bayh]] introduced the [[Family Entertainment Protection Act]], which called for a federal mandate enforcement of the ESRB ratings system in order to protect children from inappropriate content.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2005/12/16/family-entertainment-protection-act-now-filed/|title=Family Entertainment Protection Act Now Filed|author=Jennie Lees|publisher=''[[Engadget]]''|date=16 December 2005|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
On January 27, 2006, the city of [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] filed a lawsuit against [[Take-Two Interactive]], the game's publisher, accusing the company of failing to disclose the game's sexual content.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/uncategorized/2006/01/6067-2/|title=Take-Two Interactive Sued over Hot Coffee Mod|author=Eric Bangeman|publisher=''[[Ars Technica]]''|date=27 January 2006|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
On June 8, 2006, Rockstar, Take-Two and the [[Federal Trade Commission|FTC]] settled. They are required to "clearly and prominently disclose on product packaging and in any promotion or advertisement for electronic games, content relevant to the rating, unless that content had been disclosed sufficiently in prior submissions to the rating authority." Should the companies violate the settlement they are liable for $11,000 in [[civil penalty|civil penalties]].<ref name="settlement">{{cite web|last=Adams |first= David |authorlink= |coauthors= | date=2006-06-08 |url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/711/711788p1.html |title=Rockstar, FTC Settle Over Hot Coffee |work= |pages= |publisher=IGN | language= |accessdate=2006-06-16}}</ref>
=== Civil class actions === In 2006 attorneys brought several [[class action]]s alleging Take-Two committed consumer [[fraud]]. In December 2007, a settlement of the litigation was reached.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gtasettlement.com/|title=GTA Settlement|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224175535/http://www.gtasettlement.com/|archivedate=December 24, 2007}}</ref> In 2008, [[Ted Frank]] filed an objection to the settlement on the grounds that the settlement sought $1 million for [[attorney's fee|attorneys' fees]], but the total payout to class members was less than $27,000.<ref name=527GP>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamepolitics.com/2008/05/27/did-lawyers-inflate-fees-hot-coffee-class-action-suit |publisher=[[Gamepolitics.com]] |title=Did Lawyers Inflate Fees in Hot Coffee Class Action Suit? |date=2008-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906160603/http://www.gamepolitics.com/2008/05/27/did-lawyers-inflate-fees-hot-coffee-class-action-suit |archivedate=2008-09-06 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Over>{{cite web |url=http://overlawyered.com/2008/05/grand-theft-auto-class-action-settlement-26505-for-the-unrepresented-class-1-million-fee-request/ |publisher=[[Overlawyered]] |title=Grand Theft Auto: Class Action Settlement - $26,505 for the unrepresented class, $1 million fee request |date=2008-05-26}}</ref> A court hearing was already scheduled on June 25, 2008. Frank previously told GamePolitics that the lawsuits were meritless and extortionate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamepolitics.com/2008/04/29/overlawyered-blog-doesnt-think-much-of-hot-coffee-class-action-settlement |publisher=[[Gamepolitics.com]] |title=Overlawyered Disses Hot Coffee Class Action Settlement |date=2008-04-29}}</ref>
As part of the settlement, Take-Two will pay a $873,000 [[Cy-près doctrine|cy-près]] award to the National [[Parent-Teacher Association]] and the ESRB.<ref name=527GP/><ref name=Over/>
As of June 25, 2008, fewer than 2,700 claimants responded to the settlement, for which the plaintiff's attorneys expressed disappointment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/lawyers-shocked-at-lack-of-hot-coffee-claimants |title=Lawyers shocked at lack of Hot Coffee claimants |accessdate=2008-06-26 |author=Matt Martin |date=2008-06-25 |publisher=[[gamesindustry.biz]]}}</ref> Frank expressed that this was further proof that the case had no merit.
As of September 1, 2009, Take Two agreed to settle a securities class action suit related to the controversy over the game and over backdating allegations for just over $20 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS220177+01-Sep-2009+BW20090901 |title=Take-Two Interactive Software, Inc. Announces Settlement of Securities Class Action |accessdate=2009-09-01 |date=2009-09-01 |publisher=Thomson Reuters |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905190830/http://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS220177+01-Sep-2009+BW20090901 |archivedate=2009-09-05 |df= }}</ref>
